text:
Hi everyone. I'm Jennifer from English with 
Jennifer. I bet talking about the COVID pandemic

is not something you enjoy. Right? That's because 
after two years, many of us are feeling COVID

fatigue. That means we're feeling tired. Tired of 
the pandemic. Tired of hearing about the pandemic.

Frustrated at having our lives 
impacted by the pandemic.

And stressed because it seems like 
the COVID pandemic will never end.

Well, I'm an optimist at heart, and I think 
as a society we'll survive this and return

to many of the things that we took for granted 
before, like hugging and handshaking. In fact,

some things -- big and small -- are already coming 
back, like sports events. But we still live with

COVID restrictions that are in place to keep 
us safe or safer. So for now, we can't escape

all the talk about COVID, and truthfully, we need 
to inform ourselves, if not every day, then from

time to time so that we can stay up-to-date on 
what's happening and how we can protect ourselves.

When you read or listen to the 
news, you'll need a certain amount

of COVID-related vocabulary to understand. 
That's what this lesson will give you. And hey!

The great thing about studying with me 
is that you can do it without a mask,

and you can sit as close to the screen 
as you want -- no social distancing!

I mentioned COVID restrictions. These are the 
policies and practices we follow in order to

keep safe. Or at least, that's the intention 
behind them. Examples include not being allowed

to enter a store without a mask, limiting how 
many people can be in an elevator at one time,

and being asked to social distance inside 
a building, meaning we stay six feet apart.

The issue of masks is a bundle of complexities. To 
wear one or not? And if you wear one, what kind?

Disposable masks are common. 
They're designed for one-time use.

If stores or schools hand out masks for 
free, they're disposable. They have a

bendable nose guard and ear loops, 
which can break if you pull too hard.

They also sell reusable and washable masks. 
Often you can insert a filter inside.

At first we were told that medical-grade masks 
were for those working on the front lines.

now we're told that these masks are really 
the best, and we should all be wearing one.

But they're more expensive and not so easy 
to get. There are also a lot of fake N95 and

KN95 masks out there. Good masks filter 
out particles, and as we know, COVID-19

is transmitted by airborne particles and droplets. 
Droplets are small; particles are even smaller.

The latest talk is that only medical-grade masks 
really help against the Omicron variant. What

did we face before that? The Delta variant. 
"Variant" or "strain" refers to a specific

type of the virus. The virus mutates or changes, 
so over the course of the pandemic, we faced a

few different strains. Delta wasn't kind, but it 
was easier to say. I've noticed variation when

it comes to the pronunciation of Omicron. I've 
heard "oh mee," "aw mee," "oh muh," "aw muh." I

tend to go back and forth between 
"oh muh krawn" and "aw mi krawn."

As I record this video, the Omicron variant is 
still the dominant strain. Has it peaked yet? Has

it hit its high? In some places, yes, but not in 
all. Hopefully, we'll get to the point where we'll

have these little COVID outbreaks and not these 
problematic surges that sweep over the world.

Both outbreaks and surges can happen suddenly, 
but outbreaks can be relatively small. Surges

are large. We can also talk about a 
spike. That refers to a sudden increase.

The Delta surge. A COVID 
outbreak in a nursing home.

A spike in Omicron cases. A 
spike in hospitalizations.

The opposite of a surge or spike would be a 
drop or decline. A slow decline in COVID deaths.
A steady decline. A sharp decline.

By the way, at the start of the pandemic, we still 
talked about the coronavirus and COVID-19. Now two

years into this, we've shortened our references to 
COVID. COVID cases. COVID infections. Fight COVID.

A big point of debate is vaccination. The 
scientific world has developed a few different

COVID vaccines, and they all 
perform a little differently.

We can talk about their efficacy and 
learn how long our immunity lasts.

Sadly, we learned that immunity declines, so 
extra doses are needed. Pfizer and Moderna

require two doses. We used to talk about being 
fully vaccinated if a person had two doses.

Now we know that a third dose is needed after 
about six months. We call that a booster

or booster shot. If someone got the 
Johnson & Johnson or J&J vaccine,

it's recommended they get a 
dose of Pfizer or Moderna now.

At this stage of the game, some people are saying 
they're triple vaxxed. So, it looks like we may

have to constantly update our definition 
of what it means to be fully vaccinated.

How long will the booster shot last? 
We don't know for certain right now.

We do know that immunity 
wanes. It slowly decreases.

As I understand, some people are already 
getting their fourth shot, their fourth dose.

Some people ask, "Who is more immune to the 
virus?" There are those who have vaccine-induced

immunity. They've been vaccinated. Then there are 
those who have natural immunity. They're immune to

COVID for a while after being infected. There's 
also hybrid immunity: people have had COVID and

got vaccinated. A question still being asked is: 
Can we achieve herd immunity? That's when a large

portion of the population is immune through 
previous infection and/or through vaccination.

Getting a shot means getting vaccinated. 
You can get the flu shot, for example,

and it lasts for about a year. By the way, there's 
a danger now of getting the flu and COVID at the

same time. It's called flurona. Coinfections. 
Two respiratory infections at the same time.

The COVID pandemic has created a lot of 
debate around the issue of government control

and individual rights and civil liberties. Some 
governments and organizations have the authority

to issue mandates, that is, they can create 
an official order that people must follow.
Mask mandates create two camps: those for it

and those against it. The same 
thing happens with vaccine mandates.

In the U.S., it's rather complicated because 
power is shared between the federal and

state governments. And at the federal level, 
power is shared between our three branches:

executive, judicial, and legislative. If you need 
to review how the U.S. government works, you can

check out my lesson on that topic. Each country 
is figuring out how to deal with vaccination.

In every country, we can 
talk about the vaccinated,

the unvaccinated, and those not eligible 
for vaccination, like children under five.

I think compromises are often possible. 
After two years of not really going out,

I took my daughter and her friend to 
The Boston Ballet at Christmastime.

We saw The Nutcracker. COVID restrictions were 
in place. Before you could enter the theater,

you had to show proof of vaccination (your 
vaccination card) or a negative test result.

The Boston Ballet specified that it had to 
be a COVID-19 PCR test within 72 hours of

the performance or a COVID-19 rapid antigen 
test within 24 hours of the performance.

There are two kinds of COVID tests at the 
moment. PCR or molecular tests are sent to a lab.

Rapid tests or antigen tests 
can produce results in minutes.

PCR tests are considered more accurate. Have 
you ever had a COVID test? I had to do one

before my surgery back in 2020. The nasal swab 
wasn't comfortable, but thankfully it was quick.

These days American public schools are doing free 
testing when they believe that someone might be

infected because they've had close contact with 
someone who already tested positive. Someone

can get tested Then they get their results, and 
they can either test negative or test positive.

The COVID policies and guidelines change, 
but generally we can talk about isolation

and quarantine. According to the CDC, the 
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention,

"isolation separates people with a contagious 
disease from people who are not sick" and

"quarantine separates and restricts the movement 
of people who were exposed to a contagious

disease to see if they become sick." That's the 
difference between isolation and quarantine.

I hope you all have remained healthy, and if 
you've gotten sick with COVID, I hope it was

a mild case. No one wants to experience a severe 
case that requires hospitalization. Some people

who get infected with COVID are fortunate enough 
to experience only mild symptoms, like coughing

and a runny nose. Some people are infected 
and are asymptomatic: they have no symptoms.

If COVID impacted your life or a 
family member's life more seriously,

I'm truly sorry. One thing we can all do is take 
care of ourselves and keep our immunity strong,

so try to sleep well and eat well. Stay positive 
and strong. And hopefully, there won't be a need

for me to make a lot more COVID-related 
lessons in the future. Fingers crossed.
It's time to wrap up. How about a review quiz?

One. If you're feeling tired of the 
pandemic, what are you experiencing?
Pandemic fatigue. You can also say

"COVID fatigue," but this could refer 
to an actual symptom of the virus, too.
Two. When you get vaccinated once,

twice, and a third time, what is 
each time called? What do you get?

Well, you get a shot, but 
in each shot there's a dose.
Three. What are Delta and Omicron?
They're strains or variants of COVID-19.

Four. What are the limitations we live 
with to keep us safe during the pandemic?

COVID restrictions. Or you 
might say "COVID policies."

Five. What's another word for "a 
sudden increase" in COVID numbers?

A spike or a surge. And a smaller 
increase perhaps in a limited area?
An outbreak.

Six. What's another word for "a 
decrease" in the number of COVID cases?
A decline or drop.

Seven. What can an authority 
issue to make people do something?
They can issue a mandate.
Eight. What kind of COVID tests are sent to a lab?

PCR tests. Those are molecular 
tests, not rapid antigen tests.

Nine. If you have COVID but 
show no symptoms, what are you?
Asymptomatic.

Ten. If you are exposed to COVID, 
what are you supposed to do?
Quarantine.

And here are some questions for reflection. 
You can put your answers in the comments. One.

How much money have you been spending on masks 
each month? Have your habits changed since 2020?

Two. Do you anticipate that 
there will be a vaccine with

high enough efficacy to stop 
COVID fully and completely?

And here's a bonus word for you: eradicate. 
It means to eliminate or destroy completely.

Can we eradicate COVID? Can 
the virus be eradicated?

That's all for now. Please like the 
video if you found the lesson useful.

As always, thanks for watching and happy 
studies! Hey there! Did you know there are

two ways to boost your English? Go beyond my 
videos with Patreon and YouTube memberships.

Check out the video description for more 
information. Follow me on Facebook, Twitter,

and Instagram. Why not join me on Patreon? 
And don't forget to subscribe on YouTube.
